messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 60 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Deep Learning with Logical Constraints

Paper Abstract: Abstract In recent years, there has been an increasing interest in exploiting logically specified background knowledge in order to obtain neural models (i) with a better performance, (ii) able to learn from less data, and/or (iii) guaranteed to be compliant with the background knowledge itself, e.g., for safety-critical applications. In this survey, we retrace such works and categorize them based on (i) the logical language that they use to express the background knowledge and (ii) the goals that they achieve.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 60 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 60"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Logic tensor networks",
        "Hierarchical multi-label classification for protein function prediction: A local approach based on neural networks",
        "Hierarchical multi-label classification using local neural networks",
        "Your “flamingo” is my “bird”: Fine-grained, or not",
        "Label relation graphs enhanced hierarchical residual network for hierarchical multi-granularity classification",
        "Bridging machine learning and logical reasoning by abductive learning",
        "A review of some techniques for inclusion of domain-knowledge into deep neural networks",
        "The connectionist inductive learning and logic programming system",
        "Neural-symbolic computing: An effective methodology for principled integration of machine learning and reasoning",
        "Large-scale object classification using label relation graphs",
        "Bridging logic and kernel machines",
        "Integrating prior knowledge into deep learning",
        "Logic tensor networks for semantic image interpretation",
        "Neuro-symbolic constraint programming for structured prediction",
        "A hierarchical multi-label classification method based on neural networks for gene function prediction",
        "DL2: Training and querying neural networks with logic",
        "Combining prior symbolic knowledge and constructive neural network learning",
        "Fast relational learning using bottom clause propositionalization with artificial neural networks",
        "Knowledge-based connectionism for revising domain theories",
        "Coherent hierarchical multi-label classification networks",
        "Multi-label classification neural networks with hard logical constraints",
        "Distilling the knowledge in a neural network",
        "MultiplexNet: Towards fully satisfied logical constraints in neural networks",
        "Harnessing deep neural networks with logic rules",
        "Deep neural networks with massive learned knowledge",
        "An algebraic Prolog for reasoning about possible worlds",
        "Triangular Norms",
        "Learning multiple layers of features from tiny images Ch. 3",
        "DeepGO: Predicting protein functions from sequence and interactions using a deep ontology-aware classifier",
        "Augmenting neural networks with first-order logic",
        "DEEPre: Sequence-based enzyme EC number prediction by deep learning",
        "Rationale-inspired natural language explanations with commonsense",
        "DeepProbLog: Neural probabilistic logic programming",
        "LYRICS: A general interface layer to integrate logic inference and deep learning",
        "AWX: An integrated approach to hierarchical-multilabel classification",
        "Adversarially regularising neural NLI models to integrate logical background knowledge",
        "A recap of early work on theory and knowledge refinement",
        "Modeling label space interactions in multi-label classification using box embeddings",
        "ProbLog: A probabilistic Prolog and its application in link discovery",
        "Learning pipelines with limited data and domain knowledge: A study in parsing physics problems",
        "Improved protein structure prediction using potentials from deep learning",
        "Logic tensor networks: Deep learning and logical reasoning from data and knowledge",
        "Combining explanation-based learning and artificial neural networks",
        "Combining symbolic and neural learning",
        "On tractable representations of binary neural networks",
        "A survey of hierarchical classification across different application domains",
        "AI for science: Report on the department of energy (DOE) town halls on artificial intelligence (AI) for science",
        "Label-free supervision of neural networks with physics and domain knowledge",
        "Cascade ARTMAP: Integrating neural computation and symbolic knowledge processing",
        "Knowledge-based artificial neural networks",
        "Analyzing differentiable fuzzy implications",
        "Analyzing differentiable fuzzy logic operators",
        "Informed machine learning—A taxonomy and survey of integrating prior knowledge into learning systems",
        "Hierarchical multi-label classification networks",
        "When a computer program keeps you in jail: How computers are harming criminal justice",
        "Hyper-class augmented and regularized deep learning for fine-grained image classification",
        "Embedding symbolic knowledge into deep networks",
        "A semantic loss function for deep learning with symbolic knowledge",
        "NeurASP: Embracing neural networks into answer set programming",
        "mlDEEPre: Multi-functional enzyme function prediction with hierarchical multi-label deep learning"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 60 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Deep Learning with Logical Constraints, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
